clinical_study.brief_title: Prevalence of Sarcopenia and Undernutrition in Patients With Cirrhosis and Abdominal Hernia
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence of Sarcopenia and Undernutrition in Patients With Cirrhosis and Abdominal Hernia

brief_summary.textblock: The study evaluates whether sarcopenia influences the prevalence of abdominal hernias in patients with cirrhosis.

detailed_description.textblock: Sarcopenia is a common condition in patients with cirrhosis, with a prevalence of around 50%. It is unknown if the presence of sarcopenia may influence the prevalence of abdominal hernias in this group of patients. Clinical, nutritional and radiological evaluation will be performed in two groups of cirrhotic patients to evaluate this hypothesis.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion (an average of 1 year)
primary_outcome.description: Prevalence of Sarcopenia in patients with cirrhosis

primary_outcome.measure: Influence of Sarcopenia in Prevalence of Abdominal Hernias in Patients with Cirrhosis
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion (an average of 1 year)
primary_outcome.description: Influence of Sarcopenia in Prevalence of Abdominal Hernias in Patients with Cirrhosis

arm_group.description: This group consists of cirrhotic patients with any abdominal hernia
This group consists of cirrhotic patients without any hernias

intervention.description: The results of the CT scan and the hand-grip test will be used for diagnosis of sarcopenia. The Royal Free Hospital-Global Assessment (RFH-GA) results will classify the nutritional status of the patient.

study_pop.textblock: Tertiary care adult patients with cirrhosis, with and without abdominal hernias.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ≥ 18 years
- Previous diagnosis of cirrhosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- Acutely decompensated cirrhosis
- Other chronic diseases in advanced stage (e.g. cardiac failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cancer)
- Cognitive impairment, delirium, non-controlled psychosis
